hedline.hl1: Metro Business; Spanish Newscast Is Tops

abstract.p: Audience analysis finds that evening newscast of New York's most prominent Spanish-language television station, WPIX, beat WCBS, WABC and WNBC among 18- to 49-year-old viewers during July sweeps (S)

block.p: The evening newscast of New York's most prominent Spanish-language television station, WPIX, beat WCBS, WABC and WNBC among 18- to 49-year-old viewers during the July sweeps, according to a recently released audience analysis. WPIX, a Univision affiliate that is broadcast on Channel 41, had an estimated 272,000 viewers between 18 and 49 years old for its ''Noticias Univision,'' which is broadcast from 6 to 6:30 p.m. weekdays.

According to the analysis, which is based on the Nielsen Hispanic Index, WABC's ''Eyewitness News'' had an estimated 253,000 viewers in that age group, WNBC's ''Newschannel 4 at 6'' had an estimated 193,000 of those viewers and WCBS's ''News 2 at 6'' had an estimated 65,000 viewers.

The evening newscast of New York's most prominent Spanish-language television station, WPIX, beat WCBS, WABC and WNBC among 18- to 49-year-old viewers during the July sweeps, according to a recently released audience analysis. WPIX, a Univision affiliate that is broadcast on Channel 41, had an estimated 272,000 viewers between 18 and 49 years old for its ''Noticias Univision,'' which is broadcast from 6 to 6:30 p.m. weekdays.

According to the analysis, which is based on the Nielsen Hispanic Index, WABC's ''Eyewitness News'' had an estimated 253,000 viewers in that age group, WNBC's ''Newschannel 4 at 6'' had an estimated 193,000 of those viewers and WCBS's ''News 2 at 6'' had an estimated 65,000 viewers.
The ratings mark the second time that WPIX has beaten all three major networks in the 18- to 49-year-old group, which is highly prized by advertisers.

Correction: September 27, 2000, Wednesday A report in the Metro Business column on Thursday about the high ratings of Univision's Spanish-language newscast among viewers 18 to 49 years old misidentified the network's New York affiliate. It is WXTV, not WPIX.
